text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with pecans sour cream coffee cake
that's right i'm going to show you how
to make a cake specifically engineer to
go with coffee and when it comes to
these kind of cakes i think everyone
agrees that the best part is that crumb
filling / topping and because of that
fact what we've done here is doubled
maybe even tripled the amount of crumb
mixture normally called for in these
recipes and the results really were
amazing in fact I almost titled this
recipe the ultimate pecan sour cream
coffee cake but I didn't because really
that's up to you to decide but I really
did love how this came out
so let's go ahead and get started with
the first of three very simple
components the pecan crumb topping /
filling before that we're going to start
with about a cup and a half of chopped
pecans and then to our nuts we're going
to add some sugar in two forms we'll do
some light brown sugar as well as some
white sugar we will also add a nice big
spoon of cinnamon as well as a pinch of
salt and then last but not least we will
drizzle in some melted butter and then
we'll take a spatula and mix all that
together and once that's been
accomplished our crumb topping / filling
is done and by the way you want to do a
very thorough job of combining this
stuff okay we want to make sure all
these ingredients are completely and
thoroughly coated with that melted
butter so take your time and give it a
good mix until you have something that
looks like this at which point we can
set that aside and move on to the dry
ingredients and that's going to start
with some regular all-purpose flour -
which we're going to add some salt and
then we're also going to need some
baking powder as well as its good friend
baking soda and at this point if we were
our grandparents we would sift this but
we're not so we'll take a whisk and use
the modern method of simply mixing this
for about a minute and as soon as that's
mixed up we'll set that aside and move
on to the last component the wet
ingredients and ideally that's supposed
to begin with some malleable
room-temperature butter but I forgot to
take my neither fridge so I popped in
the microwave for a few seconds on
defrost to kind of soften it up a little
bit which sort of worked but I was
worried about it melting so I stopped
and just decided to use it like this so
hopefully you'll remember to leave your
butter out because it does make this
next step much easier because what we're
going to do is dump in some sugar and
use a spatula to cream it into that
butter
can see if your butter is still a little
too cold like mine is it just makes a
little more difficult but have you said
that a little too firm is always better
than a little too soft and I'm assuming
I'm not the first person that's ever
said that but anyway we're going to
continue working the sugar and butter
together with our spatula until it's
been smooshed and smeared together and
look something like this
at which point we're going to stop and
add two whole eggs but not at once
alright we want to add these one at a
time which is going to make it a lot
easier to mix in
so we'll crack in an egg and we'll take
a whisk and we will mix that in and as
you may know from previous recipes where
we've done this when you first start
mixing the egg into the butter and sugar
mixture it doesn't look great okay it's
not going to look like it wants to mix
and will kind of look separated and like
something went horribly wrong but do not
be concerned just keep whisking and as
you'll see in just a few seconds the
mixture will come together and to kind
of a smooth sticky mass and once that
happens we can go ahead and add the
second egg in which always mixes in much
easier than the first one so we will add
that second egg and we will mix it in
and as soon as that's done we can go
ahead and add the last couple wet
ingredients which includes some vanilla
extract of course the real stuff
remember real chefs never use fake
vanilla and then we'll finish this off
with a cup of sour cream
of course you'll get extra credit if you
use homemade creme fraiche for this
which I didn't but it would be amazing
and then we'll go ahead and mix that up
with our whisk and once that's at we'll
go ahead and finish off this batter by
whisking in our dry ingredients so we
will dump our flour mixture in and this
is by no means difficult but one thing I
want to point out you see how when I'm
stirring here some of the flour flew out
of the bowl try to make sure slower and
more carefully so that doesn't happen so
that's just me rushing whoops I did it
again and besides not losing flour the
other thing is we don't want to over mix
this so we're only going to stir that
till the flour disappears and then we're
going to stop okay right there is
perfect and once that's been combined we
can move on to final assembly and what
that means is we're going to transfer
exactly one half of this batter into the
bottom of a buttered baking dish and
we'll spread that out as even as we can
about to hedge our bats when we're done
and we'll give it the old tap etapa as
well as the old
sheikha to settle that batter down at
which point we're going to stop and
scatter over exactly one half of our
crime mixture just try to distribute
that as evenly as you can and then what
we want to do is just give it a very
gentle pressing with our fingertips not
too much just ever so slightly press
that down with your fingertips we don't
want to press it flat or actually into
the batter too much but just settle that
down a little bit and once that's done
we'll go ahead and top that with the
rest of the batter and then what we'll
attempt to do is spread this over
without disrupting that layer of crumbs
if we can help it
which is not easy because this stuff is
very thick and very sticky which is why
right here I decide to switch from the
spatula to this smaller thinner spreader
and like I said we're going to spread
that over disturbing that layer of
crumbs as little as possible but as you
can see some of those crumbs are going
to mix into that top layer which is not
a problem as you'll see once this bakes
it looks amazing but anyway we'll spread
over the rest of the batter doing as
little damage as possible at which point
we will finish this off by spreading
over the rest of the crumb mixture and
by the way some cooks to make this
easier don't do a center layer of crumbs
they'll transfer in their batter and
they'll just do one layer of crumbs on
top and while that may be a little
easier I much prefer the texture and the
appearance of this method but anyway
that's up to you you are there Drake of
your coffee cake speaking of which we
started from the bottom now we're here
and we'll finish this process by
ever-so-slightly pressing those crumbs
into the surface not too hard just a
nice light pressing and then other than
cleaning it off a little schmutz around
the edge with a paper towel this is
ready to bake so let's go ahead and
transfer that into the center of a 350
degree oven for about 35 minutes or so
or until it looks like this that top
will have formed that signature crispy
crunchy surface and how we're going to
know for sure it's done is with a bamboo
skewer if we stick that in somewhere
near the center it should come out clean
you see that or if you pull that out and
still has sticky batter on it it needs
more time and then assuming our cake is
cooked long enough we only have to do
one more thing which is by far the
hardest part of this recipe we want to
let this cool down completely before we
cut it and serve it which I did so this
is a couple hours later and right here
you're going to get your first look at
why we took the trouble to do that
Center layer of crumbs
because not only does that give this at
signature appearance but we're also
going to get not one but two distinctly
different textures with that crumb
mixture
okay the stuff on top gets kind of
crispy and crunchy
while the stuff in the inside stays kind
of moist and buttery and for me that's
the magic of this cake the combination
of those two different textures of crumb
combined with that beautiful tender
buttery not too sweet cake it was just
incredible and an absolutely amazing
pairing with this make-believe coffee so
good but anyway that's it pecan a sour
cream coffee cake looks great tastes
great and super easy to make in fact if
you're one of these people that never
has any luck making cakes
make this recipe it is virtually
impossible to screw up
and no I don't believe in jinxes well in
sports yes but in cookie none so I
really do hope you give this a try soon
head over to food wishes comm for all
the agreement amounts and wonderful as
usual and as always enjoy
